summary.p: [News:] The Imperial Diet [at Worms] is further delayed until the envoy [of Charles V, Johann d’Andelot,] returns from Rome. The Emperor has submitted to the Council [of Trent] and thus cannot grant the Protestants a lasting peace. Therefore, they will not approve the financial aid tied to a peace agreement. However, there is a fear that the Emperor will grant an ultimately invalid sham peace [to obtain the money]. - [Elisabeth of Austria, Queen of Poland], the daughter of Ferdinand [I.], died after a short illness [on June 15, 1545], thus Ferdinand paid the dowry in vain. - [Elector Frederick II of the Palatinate] has entered into an alliance with [Ulrich of] Württemberg. Also, [William of] Bavaria and Landgrave [Philip of Hesse] are on friendly terms with each other. - The [Constance] canons have submitted a supplication against the Bishop of Constance [Johann von Weeze] [at the Imperial Diet in Worms], which was read in the Imperial Council amid laughter. - Blarer can no longer delay the messenger [...]. Greetings. - [P.S.:] A truce is said to have been concluded with the Turk [Sultan Suleiman I.].

div.p: The decision of the Imperial Diet is pending and will be delayed until the Emperor's envoy returns from Rome. The Emperor has submitted to the Council and agreed to be obedient, which is why he cannot grant the Protestants a lasting peace; therefore, the money that was approved to be paid - but with the condition that a lasting peace is achieved - will not be given. However, there is concern that the Emperor will grant a sham peace, which will be disputable and not valid.

The daughter of Ferdinand, the Queen of Poland, was healthy and then dead within three days. And the king, nevertheless, dispatched a hundred thousand guilders for the dowry in a few days; thus, both life and goods are gone together.
Also, the Elector Palatine is doing very well. He has allied with Württemberg. Likewise, Bavaria and the Landgrave are on brotherly terms with each other; it will be announced shortly.
Our canons have submitted a sharp supplication against our Bishop of Constance. It was read in the Imperial Council, and everyone laughed.
I cannot delay the departing and waiting messenger. Farewell. I was not allowed to add anything. July 22.
A truce with the Turk is confirmed.
